title: The Green
listingDescription: Across from the Bookshop, visitors can enjoy the scenic views offered by the Shenandoah. The Green is a natural highlight in historic Lower Town and is often a starting point for tours and activities.

images.altText: A green lawn in front of a railroad track
images.title: The Green
images.caption: The Green

bodyText: Across from the Bookshop, The Green offers scenic views of the Shenandoah River. It is a natural highlight in historic Lower Town and is often a starting point for tours and activities.

title: The Point, Harpers Ferry
listingDescription: Today's view of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers passing through the water gap in the Blue Ridge Mountains has changed little from Meriwether Lewis' view in 1803. Lewis hoped to find a similar, accessible trade route on the rivers passing through the Rocky Mountains.

images.altText: This is a scenic image of the meeting point of the Potomac and Shenandoah. A massive river runs through mountain ranges on either side of it. The mountains are lush and green and stretch off into the distance. A metal bar crosses the front of the river to protect people from falling in.

bodyText: Visit where the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers meet! From this location, known as The Point, you look upon three states - Maryland, Virginia, and West Virginia - as well as the confluence of the two rivers. We invite you to visit in any season to gaze upon the magnificent sight of this water gap in the Blue Ridge Mountains.

title: Train Station

images.altText: A large red building with a tower on the right side. Cars line up in front of the building.
images.title: Train Station
images.caption: Train station

bodyText:
The Amtrak station in Harpers Ferry consists of a platform with shelter adjacent to the historic wood-frame depot, which was designed in 1894 by architect E. Francis Baldwin for the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad (B&O). Baldwin, a Baltimore resident, built 136 train stations and more than 500 other buildings during a 50-year career. 

Throughout the years, the depot has been altered many times and moved from its original location overlooking the scenic confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac Rivers in 1931, as a part of a series of railroad improvements, and now sits on part of the old Armory foundations.

*Parking is extremely limited at this site. Please consider parking at the main entrance on 171 Shoreline Drive and riding the park shuttle bus to Lower Town.*
audioDescription: Long, rectangular wooden building painted dark red, with a roofed cupola addition blanketed by windows rising from the right side of the building above the first story. Four windows are placed symmetrically along its length, and there are two entrances placed at either end of the building. A white-and-black rectangular sign above the left entrance reads waiting room. Eaves jut out and support the roof. A roofed area behind the station sits above the train tracks.

title: Turbine Pit
listingDescription: Located in lower Hall's Island, the Turbine Pit is the ruined structure that once held two Boyden turbines for the Tilt Hammer Shop at the Rifle Factory. Visit this site to gain a better understanding of industry during this period.

images.altText: Shot of where old turbines used to be located. It is hard to make out due to how much grass and dirt have covered it, but the area is visible and in the middle of a forest-like area with several trees.

bodyText: Located in lower Hall's Island, the Turbine Pit is the ruined structure that once held two Boyden turbines for the Tilt Hammer Shop at the Rifle Factory. Visit this site to gain a better understanding of industry during this period.

images.altText: Old turbine ruins in between two brick walls.

title: United States Arsenal Ruins
listingDescription: The federal government constructed two arsenal buildings at Harpers Ferry to store the weapons produced at the armory. In 1859 there were 100,000 weapons stored in the arsenal buildings, which played a role in the John Brown raids.

images.altText: Current photograph of Arsenal Ruins
images.title: Current photograph of Arsenal Ruins
images.caption: Current photograph of Arsenal Ruins

bodyText:
The federal government constructed two arsenal buildings at Harpers Ferry to store the weapons produced at the armory. In 1859 there were 100,000 weapons stored in the arsenal buildings, which played a role in the John Brown raids. Brown intended to use firearms seized at Harpers Ferry to commence a war to end slavery, but failed to do so. Sixteen months later, at the outbreak of the Civil War, only 15,000 weapons were stored at Harpers Ferry. The years between John Brown's raid and the Civil War, the majority of the arms at the United State Arsenal were distributed to Southern states under the instruction of Secretary of War John B. Floyd, a politician who was loyal to Southern interests.

When Virginia seceded from the Union, in 1861, Governor John Letcher ordered the Virginia militia to seize the armory and arsenal at Harpers Ferry. Captain Turner Ashby led the militia towards Harpers Ferry and once they were close they could hear an explosion. The two arsenal buildings were set ablaze by the retreating Union forces, under Lt. Roger Jones command, and 15,000 weapons were destroyed.

Close to 100 years after the Civil War, the National Park Service's archeologists discovered the original foundations of the two arsenal buildings, which buried for generations. They also found thousands of pieces of burned weapons, which included melted and twisted barrels, bayonets, ramrods, and lock plates. Today the arsenal ruins are outlined to attain a better understanding of their role in Harpers Ferry's history.

title: Virginius Island Footbridge

images.altText: A train rolls on tracks beyond a wooden footbridge in dark woods.
images.title: Virginius Island Footbridge
images.caption: Virginius Island Footbridge

bodyText: The Virginius Island and Hall’s Island trails wind through riparian forest, past mill, turbine, and waterworks ruins, and the site of John Hall’s Rifle Works. These trails offer great opportunities to see the Shenandoah River, spring wildflowers, birds, and river wildlife.

title: Virginius and Hall's Islands
listingDescription: Explore Virginius and Hall's Islands to discover how nature has reclaimed a place that was once full of factories and mills, canals and homes. Count how many birds, reptiles, and amphibians you see in this park area. Learn what the ruins used to be while strolling along the banks of the Shenandoah River. Walk to this location from Lower Town or from the Harpers Ferry NHP Visitor Center.

images.altText: A wooden trestle on stone pillars crosses a creek into some woods.
images.title: Virginius and Hall's Islands
images.caption: Trail is open during daylight hours.

bodyText: Explore Virginius and Hall's Islands to discover how nature has reclaimed a place that was once full of factories and mills, canals and homes. Count how many birds, reptiles, and amphibians you see in this park area. Learn what the ruins used to be while strolling along the banks of the Shenandoah River. Walk to this location from Lower Town or from the Harpers Ferry NHP Visitor Center.

title: White Hall Tavern
listingDescription: Located directly across from the U.S. Armory, the White Hall Tavern was an 1850s community gathering place, where white males debated politics; discussed local events; and protested armory management, wages and layoffs. images.altText: A stucco building stands in contrast to surrounding brick buildings.
images.title: White Hall Tavern
images.caption: The White Hall Tavern was a popular gathering spot in the 1850s.

bodyText: Located directly across from the U.S. Armory, the White Hall Tavern was an 1850s community gathering place, where white males debated politics; discussed local events; and protested armory management, wages and layoffs. The tavern's close proximity easily tempted armory workers to raise a glass, or two...or three, before and during work. As a result, Armory officials took a stand that public houses, such as the White Hall Tavern, ruined morals, work ethics, and even threatened armory production. Crowded building conditions posed another threat -- fire. In 1856 the U.S. Government purchased and removed the front section of the building. They subsequently widened the street, creating the needed safety buffer around the Armory.
audioDescription: Located directly across from the U.S. Armory, the White Hall Tavern was an 1850s community gathering place, where white males debated politics; discussed local events; and protested armory management, wages and layoffs. title: Winchester and Potomac Railroad

images.altText: An elevated train track on wooden beams runs parallel to a roadway.
images.title: Winchester and Potomac Railroad
images.caption: Choo choo! Look up, and maybe you'll spot a passing train!

bodyText: The Winchester & Potomac railroad companies laid the first tracks in the mid-1830s. Today, the line belongs to CSX and is heavily trafficked by its trains. Rangers and visitors often wave to the engineers, who sometimes return greetings with a few rings of the bell or a quick blast on the horn. They are a favorite sight and sound in the Ferry.
